titleStmt.title: Grammar of Tamil (cen tamiḻ), by Beschi

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

summary.p: This manuscript reproduces the Latin grammar of the High Tamil (centamiḻ) composed by the Italian Jesuit Giuseppe Costantino Beschi (1680-1740).

support.p: There is watermark that is also found in other manuscripts (i.e. Indien 189, Indien 190, and Indien 634 – see Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 67). It is represented by the letter T surmounted by a crown and placed on a base, itself surmounting a cartouche which contains a J followed by a fleur-de-lis and the name CUSSON (cf. nos. 3292 and 3293, pl. 424 and no. 694, pl 109 in Heawood 1969 [1950]).

layout.p: There are approx. 33-37 lines per page.

desc.p: Filliozat (1937: 283, fn. 1) states that this is a copy made by Abraham-Hyacinthe Anquetil-Duperron (1731-1805) (see Fr. Nouv. Acq. 22436 for an example of his handwriting). However, the handwriting in this manuscript seems to be similar to Jean Calmette's (1692-1739 or 1740) one. As he declares in a letter sent from Ballabaram in 1732, he was among those Jesuits who copied some of the manuscripts sent to the Royal Library (fond Brotier 89, fol. 37a, 37b cited in Colas and Chauhan 1995: 11).
puḷḷi is marked only on cinna ra otherwise is not regularly used.
Double-curled kompu is not used. The differentiation between o/ō, e/ē is marked by a stroke placed above the letter in order to mark the short C.
Differentiation between ra/ā is marked by a stroke palced above it. The periya ra is transrcibed with a double loop.

decoNote.desc: At the beginning of each page there is a cross to mark that it is a Christian manuscript. The cross is placed in the upper side of the page in a centered position.

additions.desc: CCMBR number: n. 282 (= Ancient fond, n° CCLXXXII, p. 448).

It is found at the beginning of the manuscript, on f. 1r, and at the end, on f. 81r. The stamp used is a red circle with a double line containing 3 fleurs-de-lil summounted by a crown with the inscription Bibliotheque Royal. This stamp is a variant of the stamp n. 21 in Josserand and Bruno (1960: 281) in use during the Restauration (July 1830 to half January 1831).

p.p: Apparently, the stiff covers (boards) at the front and back of the book are attached to the quires by the cords which are secured by means of channeling.

The boards and spine are covered with paper which is folded over the edges of the boards forming a turn-ins and glued down. Pastedowns of an initial and a final bifolios onto the inside of the board partially conceal these mechanism of the binding and also the channeling. The manuscript is made of 33 queris of six or three bifolios.

origin.origDate: In Vinson (1867: 49 and 1867-1868: 46) and Vinson and Feer (1866-: 46) the date is 1760 however being mentioned in the CCMBR (1739: 448) the date must be anticipated. Indeed, in Cabaton (1912: 32) the same date has been corrected with an annotation in 1739. However, the possibility of considering this manuscript as copied by Calmette allows to move the date further back up to 1730, even though it is not listed among the manuscripts that Jesuits sent to France in order to enrich the Royal Library (see Omont 1902; Colas 1997).

encodingDesc.p: Transliteration conventions ― Conservative. Hence, puḷḷi, ō, and ē are used only if they are found in the manuscript. ― Abbreviations ― C = consonant, cf. = compare, f. = folio, ff. = folios, fn. = footnote, r. = recto.
